thread.title: Jenkins kicking gives Columbia an edge
thread.title_full: Jenkins kicking gives Columbia an edge

author: Neighbor Newspapers (noreply@neighbornewspapers.com)
title: Jenkins kicking gives Columbia an edge
text: slideshow There is a feeling of relief that comes over the Columbia varsity football team when its offense gets inside the 40-yard line of the end zone.Even if head coach David Edwards offense is unable to score a touchdown, it has its ace in the hole, or better, a “toe at the ready,” which can almost guarantee the team at least a three-point field goal.That “talented toe,” as Edwards calls it, is on the right foot of his field goal, punter, kickoff and placekicking specialist, Joshua Jenkins, who has already established an outstanding scoring record, even as a junior.The 5-foot-six, two-year varsity starter, who was the Eagles’ back-up kicker last year, already has a 44-yard field goal to his credit this year as well having a 38-yard punting average and has connected on each of his point-after-touchdown attempts this year.However, Edwards is just as proud of Jenkins’ kickoffs, of which 88 percent have landed so far back in the opponent‘s end zone that the kickoff receiver can only down the ball in the end zone for a touchback.“Kicking is his specialty and Joshua is committed to enhancing and perfecting it in such a way that it may earn him a college football scholarship upon graduation,” Edwards said.Like a painter perfecting his artwork with constant effort to improve, Jenkins works tirelessly on the “art” of kicking.That effort is no better seen then during the summer when he and his father find a football field with goal posts where Jenkins can not only practice his PAT’s and field goals but his punting and kickoffs.“My dad and I go out to a field about three times a day during the summer and, as much as possible during the school year when football season is not under way, so I can work on my kicking,” Jenkins said.However, his concentration on kicking certainly hasn’t interfered with his academic success as Jenkins is carrying a 3.95 grade point average, Edwards said.“Joshua is totally committed and dedicated to his craft and it has positively impacted the entire team as well,” he said, adding Columbia’s 9-6 victory over Redan last month was strictly due to Jenkins’ field goals.As to his approach to kicking or punting, Jenkins said he blocks everything out of his mind when he trots onto the field, “as it is just me, my holder, the long snapper and the ball,” he said.
